Word.EngDesc: The a (ั) is pronounced like in bar, car or cut
The æ (แ) is pronounced like (british) bag, care or Rabbit
The ai (ใ) is pronounced like in die, eye or Thai
The am (ำ) is pronounced like in (british) rum
The e is (เ) pronounced like in get, jet, let
The ea (เีย) is pronounced like in beer, dear, gear.ร์ is not pronounced following the rules to closing sounds
The ee ี is pronounced like in bee, sea
The ee (เ) is pronounced like in bread, dead
The g (ก) is pronounced like in get, go, grand
The h (ห) is pronounced like in hand, hard
the i (ิ) is pronounced like in bit, Italy, sit
The o (โ) is pronounced like in hope, toe, tone
The eer (เิ) is pronounced like in Bird, Burn, term, girl
The aaw (อ) is pronounced like in aunt, ball, dog
The oo (ุ) is pronounced like in butcher, put
The y is pronounced like in year, yes
The uaa (ัว) is pronounced like in tour, poor
Simply has to be practiced with sound
Simply has to be practised with sound

Word.ThaiScript: ก จ ฎ ฏ ด ต บ ป อ
Word.ThaiFonet: go jo cho bo do dto bo bpo o
Word.EngDesc: These are the consonants with the normal tone class
There are 3 closing sounds called stop sounds
This า is pronounced as a long A.

Word.EngWord: You, she, he, Ms, Mrs, Mr, sir
Word.EngDesc: This า is pronounced short, notice how similar it is to ทาน
In most cases the long vowel เออ changes to เิ when followed by another consonant. Therfor yuo should not write it as เกอน.

Word.ThaiScript: เสียง สามัญ
Word.EngDesc: The normal tone.

Word.ThaiScript: เสียง เอก
Word.EngDesc: The low tone. also know as the second tone.
The letter combination ทร is usually pronounced as S
This is how you say a child.

Word.ThaiScript: เด็ก เด็ก
Word.EngDesc: Thai nouns don't have a grametical gender, no articles and no plural forms. but there is a classifier system for the correct use of nouns
In Thai the gender of the speaking person is important. chan is used by women.
In Thai particles are used to show emotion and politness to the one you are speaking too.
In Thai particles are used to show emotion and politness to the one you are speaking too. Ka is used by women.
1000 is หนึ่งพัน (neung pan) and onwards untill 10 000.
Morning hours between 1:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m.
Low tone and unwritten o.
สี (see) is the word for color. Traditionally wwomen used to dress in red on Sundays.

Word.ThaiScript: ข ฃ ฉ ฐ ถ ผ ฝ ศ ษ ส ห
Word.ThaiFonet: ko ko cho to to po fo so so so ho
Word.EngDesc: These are the consonants with the High tone class

Word.ThaiScript: ค ฅ ฆ ง ช ซ ฌ ญ ฑ ฒ ณ ท ธ น พ ฟ ภ ม ย ร ล ว ฬ ฮ

There are 3 closing sounds called stop sounds called Nasal sounds

Word.ThaiScript: ฉ ซ ฌ ผ ฝ ฟ ห ฮ

EngWords.string: Words never stop with any of these.

Word.EngWord: Words never stop with any of these.
Word.EngDesc: These 8 letters never occure at the end of a word.

Word.ThaiScript: ญ ร ล ฬ > น
Word.EngDesc: These 4 letters changes the sound น (no) if at the end of a word.

Word.ThaiScript: ข ค ฆ > ก
Word.EngDesc: The three kho sounds changes into a K (The consonant ก changes sound from g to k at the end of a word).
The three sounds for ph- turns into pho or bo

Word.ThaiScript: ฎ ฏ ด ต > ต
Word.EngDesc: The four d sounds mostly keep their sound or turn into dt-

Word.ThaiScript: จ ช ฐ ฑ ฒ ถ ท ธ ศ ษ ส > ต
Word.ThaiFonet: jo, cho, tho ,tho, tho ,tho ,tho, tho, so, so, so > dto
Word.EngDesc: The letters with the sounds j, t, s, and ch turn into dt.
In most cases the long vowel เออ changes to เิ when followed by another consonant. Therfor yuo should not write it as เดอน.
This word has the symbol ็ above the consonant, and indicates that the vowel is short.
This word is hard to read for a foreigner as it only contains consonants, but in Thai ther are often a unwritten vowel with either the sound a or o.
To say this word (and many other words) you say an o between the consonants.
To say this word (and many other words) you say an o between the consonants.
Sometimes you have to add an additional a between consonants.
Sometimes you have to add an additional a between consonants.
There are many words where the a is written.
There are many words where thhe a is written.
There are a few words with an additional aaw.
There are a few words with an additional aaw
The Falling tone. also know as the third tone.

Word.ThaiScript: เสียง ตรี
Word.EngDesc: The high tone. also know as the Fourth tone.

Word.ThaiScript: เสียง จัตวา
Word.EngDesc: The Rising tone. also know as the fifth tone.
Consonant is of the normal tone class and has a short vowel, making the word pronounced with a low tone.
Consonant is of the normal tone class and has a stop sound, making the word pronounced with a low tone.

Word.ThaiScript: ็ = ไม้ ได่ คู้
Word.EngDesc: This is the thai name of this symbol. It is placed above the consonant and indicates that the vowel has to be pronounced short.
To pronounce this word you need to add an additional o between ม and ก.
Consonant is of the normal tone class and has a long vowel sound, making the word pronounced with a normal tone.
Consonant is of the normal tone class and has a nasal sound, making the word pronounced with a normal tone.
[word added by a female speaker to the end of every question to convey politeness] Consonant is of the low tone class and has a short vowel, making the word pronounced with a high tone.
Thai transcription of the foreign loanword. Consonant is of the high tone class and has a stop sound, making the word pronounced with a low tone.
Consonant is of the high tone class and has a long vowel, making the word pronounced with a rising tone.

EngWords.string: the long line of the back

Word.EngWord: the long line of the back; backbone; knife edge
Word.EngDesc: Consonant is of the high tone class and has a nasal sound, making the word pronounced with a rising tone.
Consonant is of the low tone class and has a short vowel and a stop sound, making the word pronounced with a high tone.

EngWords.string: to take up by means of forceps

Word.EngWord: to grip, to take up by means of forceps, tongs pincers or chopsticks, to nip
Word.EngDesc: Consonant is of the low tone class and has a long vowel and a stop sound, making the word pronounced with a falling tone.

Word.EngWord: namely; as follows; thus; as in; to wit; simply; that is
Word.EngDesc: Consonant is of the low tone class and has a long vowel, making the word pronounced with the normal tone.

EngWords.string: or feel a need to scratch or sneeze

Word.EngWord: to itch; or feel a need to scratch or sneeze
Word.EngDesc: Consonant is of the low tone class and has a nasal sound, making the word pronounced with the normal tone.

Word.ThaiScript: ๋ = ไม้ จัตวา
Word.EngDesc: Name of the symbol for the rising tone
This mark has two names and it indicates that the consonant is silent and not pronounced.
This mark indicates repetition. The word is said twice which is important for the plkural or emphasize of things.
This mark indicates what should follow is understod. E.g. Bangkok, the 'City of Angels'.
This mark has the same meaning as so on or et cetera.
The initial consonant is silent and only affect the tone. This word gets a falling tone.
The initial consonant is silent and only affect the tone. This word get a rising tone.

Word.EngWord: don't...; do not...; don't be...; doesn't
Word.EngDesc: The initial consonant is silent and only affect the tone. This word get a low tone.
The initial consonant is silent and only affect the tone. This word get a low tone.

Word.EngWord: variety; style; pattern; type; kind; sort; mode; manner; method
Word.EngDesc: The initial consonant is silent and only affect the tone. This word get a low tone.

Word.EngWord: is (located at); to reside; to live (at); stay
Word.EngDesc: The initial consonant is silent and only affect the tone. This word get a low tone.

The letter combination รร can be pronounced as "an" or "a".

Word.EngWord: [is] usual; ordinary; normal; average; plain; regular; natural; common
Word.EngDesc: The letter combination รร can be pronounced as "an" or "a".
When ร is the closing sound it changes the vowel before it from an o (โอ) to an aaw (อ).
When ร is the closing sound it changes the vowel before it from an o (โอ) to an aaw (อ).
when the letters ร, ล or ว is the second consonant in a word it can either be pronounced together with the first consonant or with an additional a.
when the letters ร, ล or ว is the second consonant in a word it can either be pronounced together with the first consonant or with an additional a.
